Name: Bridges and Boats
Description:
Equipment:

* set of double 6 dominoes (28 dominoes)
    * big pile of pennies or counters
    * 2 six-sided dice

Bridges and Boats is a strategic war game in which the attacker is trying to get soldiers across a major river while the enemy tries to stop them.

How to Win: The game ends immediately when the last domino is taken from the resource pool. At game end the attacker wins if more soldier units have crossed the river than the defender has collected units of money. Otherwise the defender wins. If the soldier/money unit count is tied at endgame then the conflict is tied; so be it.

Name: Tavern Heroes
Description:
A game in which players play boastful, drunken knights at a bar, making descending bids over how little weapons or armor they need to defeat a dragon.

Eventually, one knight will have his bid challenged, and he will have to attempt to make his bravery stand up.  The other players make bets on the outcome.  Hopefully the knight hasn't "enjoyed" himself at the tavern too much...

The game ends after eight dragons are challenged.

Name: Santa Fe' Trail
Description:
From the box cover:
"A game that takes you over the most famous of all trails in the days of the Indians. Travel in a covered wagon with the pioneers."

This is a basic spin and move race game.

Name: Mission Jungle
Description:
According to website:
On the trail of the missing research team of Dr. Jonah, you are deep in the heart of the tropical forest collecting clues hidden behind various expedition relics. Diamond mines, volcanoes and sacred temples appear on this journey. Keep an eye out for wild animals and try to survive in the challenging natural environment around you...Because only the most courageous will be able to uncover the true secret of the Jonah expedition.

A prized game with extended Internet play options for Mission enthusiasts. This particular game scenario includes an illustrated hexagon board, 90 cards of various direction, 7 pennants and more.

Name: Crok Crok Crok
Description:
Website says:
A game combining response and memorization skills, Crok Crok Crok is an amusing introduction to the eating habits of familiar animals. Five animals and a little boy are sitting down to eat. On the dinner table, we have an apple, egg, carrot, banana and snow peas. Roll the die to determine who eats first. We see its the monkey. Quick -- a player must grab the foods that are part of the animal's regular diet to earn food token chip. The game ends when one (or all) players collect all five food tokens.

A one-of-a-kind treasure containing 6 wooden food toys, 30 round chips, wooden die, guide card, and set of game rules. Made from recycled materials and wood with PEFC label guaranteeing sustainable forest management practices. Crok...Crok...Crok - it's the funny sound of chewing!

Name: Duel in the Dark: Early Nights
Description:
This expansion for Duel in the Dark introduces the British Wellington bomber, which allows more flexibility of movement.  It also uses twenty ground defense objects instead of forty.

Expands:

    Duel in the Dark

Name: 5th Column (fan expansion for Fortress America)
Description:
Quoted from the 5th Column Rules Introduction:

With rules easy enough for a novice to understand, yet subtle enough to delight the expert, 5th Column adds the rules and new playing pieces to add increasing realism to Milton Bradley’s Fortress America, while maintaining the game’s ease and speed of play.  5th Column adds the ability to influence your game with unconventional tactics.

Yet the new rules don’t overwhelm the old game.  A large army will still defeat a small army.  However, in a close battle, long range planning with unconventional forces can tip the balance.  New rules and plastic playing pieces are included for fifth column activities, commandeering civilian airlift capacity, radar, and fuel supplies.

Each of the 4 armies has 8 new pieces:

2 × Payoff Units (Dollar Signs)
2 × Fuel Supplies (Oil Rigs)
2 × Radar (Satellite Dishes)
2 × Airlift Units (Aircraft)

Name: Geheimnis der Detektive
Description:
A gang of robbers has stolen some valuable goods last night. This loot is still in town, but there is no relying on the police. So the players - as detectives (private eyes) - are appointed to find the loot.

The game uses a special movement system regarding the famous German pub game "Knobeln". It is all about bluffing and hunting for the best cards. Sudden events can alter the personal strategy.  Each player gets 5 small (movement) sticks.  Acting simultaneously with his neighbor both hide a certain number of sticks in their hands, then open their hands and count up the total amount.  Players may move if both hands show different numbers of sticks and the total amount does not equal 5; if you end on a loot slide check it (value 0 - 4) & keep it.  If a player lands on another player, it offers you an opportunity to steal.  If the stick-count equals 5 players add a barrier, and an equal number of sticks held by each player forces them back to the starting point, and they draw an event card.

Name: Annex
Description:
The game comes with 132 letter tiles in four colors, three 'wild' tiles, and a board that consists of interlocking paths. Each player draws four tiles as his or her starting hand. An additional eight tiles are drawn and turned face-up to be used as a common pool. The pool and the players' hands are replenished as the letters are used.

Players take turns placing letters onto the paths to form words. Each word must use at least one letter already on the board and at least one letter either from the common pool or from the player's hand. Words may turn corners (move from one path onto a different one) and read forward or backward, up or down. Longer words score more than shorter words; words using letters of a single color score more than words of multiple colors. The game ends when all the paths are completed or when no one can play a letter that will form a new word.

Name: De Cape & d'Épée: La mission secrète
Description:
La Mission Secrète is a mini-extension created for the Ruse & Bruise's French edition De Cape & d'Épée.

The extension slightly changes the victory conditions. Instead of giving double points if a player gets one of every objective, each player gets two missions type that will give them 3 extra points if they get a majority in a mission type.

This extension was included in the magazine Plato.

Name: Wordsworth
Description:
This is word rummy with a few twists. Players maintain a hand of letter cards by drawing, by melding words formed by the letters, and then by discarding. Players receive points for completing their required melds, for going out, for the point values of the letters in the melded words, and for the length of the melded words.

As in Phase 10, the difficulty of the required meld increases with each round: eg, two 3-letter words in Round One; one 7-letter word in the final round.

Players receive extra points for melding words that are related to the theme of the game, which is determined by drawing a card before the start of play.

Players also receive extra points for completing a bonus word that differs in each round.

Name: La Chasse au Mammouth
Description:
La Chasse au Mammouth (=Hunt for Mammoths) was published in the Swiss gaming zine "AHA/Der Schwarze Peter" #88/4.

The board shows a glacier with 6 mammoth trails and several human trails crossing them. Player camps, weapon directory, and storehouses are also on the board.

Up to 2 Mammoth herds (4 at the start of the game) enter the board every turn and travel along their trails.

Each player starts with 20 tribesmen and 5 x 5 weapons of 5 different types. The well armed tribesmen go out to hunt some mammoths, which are needed to feed the population. The weapons used to kill a mammoth are removed from the game, that is they represent more a consumable arrow than an bow, that can be used all the time.

Every second turn, it is checked to see how many tribesmen can be fed  (with half a mammoth per man).  Men who are not fed are flipped over and all their abilities are halved for the next turn. Subsequent non-feeding will result in the elimination of the men.

While hunting mammoths is relatively easy at the start of the game, it gets harder and harder, because players must manufacture new weapons and pitfalls and thus only some of the men can be used for hunting.

The game ends, when the first player has lost all tribesmen. Winner is the player who has the most surviving men on the board at that time.

Name: Das Umzugsspiel
Description:
Das Umzugsspiel ("Change of Residence") was published in the Swiss gaming zine "AHA/Der schwarze Peter" #89/1.

The board shows a fictive city map with a furniture warehouse in the middle and 4 residences in each corner.

Object of the game is to move his 7 furniture pieces from the starting residence to the residence at the opposing edge of the board with the help of 1 van per player.

Movements are done by dice rolls, but 54 also included cards influence the movements heavily. Fortunately, only 26 cards must be used immediately. The remaining 28 cards give more room to avoid too much bad luck.

4 mobile road works (=obstacles) hinder the players to move where they want and the fact that loosing furniture pieces is also possible (must be replaced by picking new furnitures in the furniture warehouse) does not only make the game more interesting, it also gives the feeling of a real change of residence - with all possible frustrating experiences.

Winner of the game is the player who has moved his furnitures to the target domicile first.

Name: Flohzirkus
Description:
Flohzirkus (="flea circus") is played on a board with 12 x 12 dots in 4 alternating colours. 5 colour dice and 2 large wooden fleas per player complete the game components.

Each flea is marked with 4 colours: 1 yellow dash at the head, 1 blue dash at the tail, 1 red flea drawing on the right side and 1 green flea drawing on the left.

Each turn, a player throws the 5 dice, which enable him to make 5 moves. Yellow, blue, red and green lets a flea jump to the 4 directions as marked on the flea, white and black enables a flea to turn in place or to shift to an adjacent dot.

Object of the game is to achieve as many points as possible, which is done by jumping over as many other fleas as possible. Winner of the game is the player with the most points after a predefined number of turns, or the one who reaches a predefined number of points first.

The game reminds at Alex Randolph's game family including "Corona"(1974), "Moonstar"(1981), "Harun"(1984), "Orbit"(1993) and "Ricochet Robots"(1999). Opposite to those games, each player has his own playing pieces in "Flohzirkus", but the lack of a time limit can be a serious problem here.

Name: Moby Dicks Freunde
Description:
Moby Dicks Freunde is played on a board with 8 x 10 rhombs. Every line of the rhomb shows a number between 1 and 6. 8 dice and 8 whales are the game components.

Each player has 4 whales, who are placed on the first 4 rhomb edges to the right. Each turn, 5-8 dice are thrown. Whales can move to adjacent rhomb edges, when the die on the board corresponds to one of the die numbers.

A restriction is that the 4 whales of a player must always form a herd, that is they must always be connected to each other.

Moving the whales on the side where the opposing herd stays is allowed, but only, if they are not blocked by such moves. Thus, a certain amount of cooperative play is requested!

Winner of the game is the player whose herd reaches the opposing side of the board first.

(Karin and Reinhold Wittig are named for the copyright of the game rules. The game is by Reinhold Wittig alone, though).

Name: Utah Trivia
Description: Utah Trivia is a party game about the state of Utah designed with several levels of difficulty so that it can be enjoyed by all ages. Players roll and move around the outside track of the board and answer questions based on the spot they land in. A unique feature in this trivia game is the players may choose to answer with or without hints.

Name: Lecardo
Description:
Lecardo is a card based game which has six games in one package, the two main games being Lecardo Football and Lecardo Farmers both of which use game 'boards'.
As a war time publication it is very minimalistic - rules and the two game boards are printed on one two-sided A3 sheet of paper; the cards each fulfill three different functions

Name: Armada
Description:
[ Note: See Armadas.pdf in the files section for a long-over due second edition with revised rules and balanced game-play. ]

Armada is a turn-based, two-player, single-stash, board-less, pure-strategy game using Icehouse Pieces. It is the age-old struggle — An unstoppable force versus an immovable object. Strength against speed. Numbers against power. This time it takes place out on the open seas. A large fleet of small, fast ships against a smaller fleet of slower, but more powerful warships. Which side will emerge the victors in this battle of the seas?

Armada appeared in Hypothermia #16.

Game System

    Icehouse Pieces

Name: Arrow Cubes
Description:
Equipment:

* 4 x 4 board
    * Two Arrow cubes -- one Red, one Black (described on the website)

Goal: Capture your opponents cube or force them to stalemate you.

Each player has a cube with arrows along the faces -- the arrow shows which side of the cube is under attack. Players take turns tipping their cubes over, trying to manoeuver into a position that will capture their opponent. A player captures their opponent when after making a legal move they are adjacent to the enemy piece and the arrow on the top face of their cube is pointing towards the enemy piece.

Name: The Assassination Game Le
Description:
A game for the piecepack.

A three-player game in which one of the players (the 'Victim') attempts to get to the four Secure Bases on the board and then return to the start position (the 'Safe House') without being eliminated by the two other players (the 'Assassins'). If the Victim is eliminated, the Assassin that eliminated him becomes the new Victim. Play continues until a Victim reaches all the Secure Bases and returns safely to the Safe House.

Name: Atomic
Description:
A game for two that's a real blast! An abstract game with a connection element -- be the player that has the most pieces showing in your color by the end of the game.

Equipment:

* An hexagonal grid, in the shape of a hexagon, containing 61 hexes.
    * Two sets of 30 double-sided hexagonal pieces:
          o 12 Connectors (one line joining two opposite sides) with the opponent's 12 Alternators on the reverse side
          o 12 Alternators (three lines joining three, alternating sides) with the opponent's 12 Connectors on the reverse side),
          o 3 Destructors (six lines joining all sides) with the opponent's 3 Burn-outs on the reverse side)
          o 3 Burn-outs (six lines joining all sides) with the opponent's 3 Destructors on the reverse side

A play consists of one of placing one marker - face-up with the colour of the player whose turn it is - on any unoccupied space on the board. The player then traces a path ('reaction') through as many pieces of the opposing colour as he can. A path is a continuous line passing from a piece of the player's colour to one of his opponent's. Once the path is established, the opponent's piece is flipped over and the piece rotated in such a way that at least one of the lines on it joins up to the path. If there are now no lines on the new piece that point to another opposing piece, or if the flipped piece is a Burn-out, the 'reaction' is over, and the player's turn ends.

The objective is for each player to have the most pieces showing his colour at the end of the game. If there are an equal number of each, the game is a draw.

Name: Hole in the Head
Description: Hole In The Head is an interesting game with even more interesting marketing by today's standards (see box photos below). The directions are on the bottom of the box and bottom of game piece. There is a hard plastic bubble-covered face with different holes in the eyes, ears, nose and mouth. There is a magnet attached to a string (inside a wooden ball) and inside the game there are 5 ball bearing type balls. You use the magnet to maneuver the balls.

Name: Official Baseball Card Game
Description:
Teams are drafted from a deck of the best players of the day. Hank Aaron, Ernie Banks, Lou Brock, Rod Carew, Roberto Clemente, Tommy Davis, Jim Fregosi, Bill Freehan, Tom Haller, Frank Howard, Reggie Jackson, Harmon Killebrew, Mickey Lolich, Juan Marichal, Willie Mays, Willie McCovey, Sam McDowell, Dennis Menke, Don Mincher, Phil Niekro, Rico Petrocelli, Boog Powell, Frank Robinson, Ron Santo, Tom Seaver, Mel Stottlemyre, and Tony Taylor are some of the players represented. Once the players have their teams each organizes a line up.

Another deck of cards represents the possible outcomes of an at bat. This deck is shuffled and one card for each player in the field is placed face down on the playing surface.

An at bat consists of rolling two six-sided dice and if the result is a two the batter has drawn a walk. Seven means a strike out. Otherwise, check for the number on the back of the batter's card. The number corresponds to a fielding position and check that fielding position of the result. An outfield result is more likely to result in a hit than an infield result. any card used is replaced from the top card of the draw pile and the deck is reshuffled when depleted. All standard rules of baseball apply.

The game is a prized collectible. Milton Bradley also released an Official Baseball board game at about the same time.

Name: Official Baseball Game
Description: Players draft teams of real players to play this simulation of America's past time. Milton Bradley released an Official Baseball Card Game at about the same time.

Name: Commodity
Description:
Commodity is a buying and selling game that is not meant to simulate real life, although there are some similarities.

Ages 12 and up can play Commodity.  Younger children can play with an adult and may even win!

The object of Commodity is:

1. To make money by buying and selling.
2. To pay off all debts.
3. To manage your company to gain wealth.

Commodity can be played to different limits which the players can set at the beginning of (or during) the game.  For example, an average game would be set at $1,000,000, a shorter game at $500,000 and a longer game at $2,000,000.

To win Commodity, a player must:

1. Be debt free.
2. Reach the limit set by the players.
3. Declare a win.

In order to declare a win, a player must state, ON HIS TURN, that he has met or gone beyond the set limit.  This player then completes his turn.  The other players now have one more turn to try and defeat the declaring player.  The player with the most money at the end wins.  A player DOES NOT have to declare a win until he chooses to do so.

See www.markallangames.com for more information.

Name: Matchless: A Bible and Nature Game
Description:
Matchless is a bible and nature card game - reinforcing knowledge of both God's Written Word and the beauty of nature.

Players must outwit their opponents and be the only player to remain matchless! Simple yet challenging, Matchless can be played again and again. The game is fresh every time.

For 3 or more players Ages 6 and up.

Name: Bible Characters Game
Description:
Coming straight from the Bible, this card game familiarizes players with important Bible characters. Playing the Bible Characters Game plugs you into the thoughts and actions of people in the Bible and challenges each player to learn, remember, and share important Bible truths.

Fun and rewarding for all ages, the Bible Characters Game keeps God’s dealings with His people in every age fresh in the minds of modern-day Christians. A biblical alternative to secular games.

For two or more players Ages 8 and up.

Name: Central Pennsylvania Trivia Game
Description:
From the publisher: This fun trivia board game brings the wonders of Central Pennsylvania to life for the entire family.

Central Pennsylvania Trivia Game is a party game about the Hershey area of Pennsylvania. It is designed with several levels of difficulty so that it can be enjoyed by all ages. Players roll and move around the outside track of the board and answer questions based on the spot they land in. A unique feature in this trivia game is the players may choose to answer with or without hints.

Name: Rose City Trivia
Description: Rose City Trivia is a party game about the city of Portland designed with several levels of difficulty so that it can be enjoyed by all ages. Players roll and move around the outside track of the board and answer questions based on the spot they land in. A unique feature in this trivia game is the players may choose to answer with or without hints. The game includes over 1,600 trivia questions!

Name: Arena
Description:
By keeping track of, and selecting, the speed of your ship you will move around an imaginable arena for space combat, where the galaxy's aces settle the score! But watch out - if you crash into the walls or any of the arenas obstacles, your ship will be hard to control. Goal of the game: To kill your opponents!

Equipment:

* As many Icehouse stashes as possible, a minimum of 1 per player
    * Tiled/checkered playing area, such as a chessboard, but the game has been optimized for a 8*8*8 board.
    * A way of indicating height if not enough pyramids are available (8-sided dice are perfect)
    * A way of indicating speed (again, 8-sided or even 6-sided (as you don't want to go very much faster than 6 in most cases) dice are good)
    * Markers to use for obstacles and power-ups, such as coins (different values of coin can be different power-ups) or Icehouse pyramids.
    * Several 8-sided die

Game System

    Icehouse Pieces

Name: One Against the Dead
Description:
One Against the Dead is a solitaire zombie game, abstracted to use a small set of components that you probably have laying around the house.

The player places cards on the table, revealing new section of the zombie-plagued city as he moves. The card placement determines numerous things; how many zombies are added to the city, which places cannot be moved through, and where various weapons and survivors that need to be rescued are. Ultimately, the goal of the game is for the player get out of the city before becoming overwhelmed by the ever-increasing zombie force that follows and blocks the player.

Name: Discombobulation
Description:
From the publisher's website:

Discombobulation is a fun, fast-paced game guaranteed to make the entire family laugh. The goal… be the first to play all of your cards before someone can discombobulate you with one of 10 unique Discombobulation challenges.

You will go head-to-head against other players to compose rhymes, sing popular songs, make lists, mimic others, remember nicknames, and much more. Mess up, you draw more cards.

Sound difficult? You bet. But outplaying your opponents in a game that requires a quick mind, fast reflexes, and a good memory makes it worth the challenge.

Name: Duel in the Dark: Baby Blitz
Description:
This expansion for Duel in the Dark is set in 1944 and enhances the German forces by giving them longer range attack capability, as well as a Mosquito killer.  The British receive an additional Mosquito.

From the publisher's website:

By late 1943, the fortunes of war had turned decidedly against Germany.
Besieged and in retreat on all fronts and faced with the inevitable invasion from the Western Allies, the Luftwaffe was ordered to re-launch bombing operations against England.

Scraping together the few remaining assets in France, to include the new He177 “Greif” (Griffon),operations began against London in January 1944. At the same time, RAF Bomber Command has been steadily increasing its nightly attacks on German cities. The successful continued bombing of Hamburg (“The Battle of Hamburg”) has led to a sustained bombing campaign over Berlin. As the chief of RAF Bomber Command, can you continue to pound the German cities, thus halting war production and driving the German population to its knees? As commander of the German Nachtjagd, will the new bombing campaign which includes the V1, the first of many new “wonder weapons” turn the tide of the war? The decisions are yours to make in “Baby Blitz”!

The new Elements of "Baby-Blitz": 
• The Game-Board of West-England 
• V1 "the flying-Bomb" 
• He 177 Bomber 
• He 219 "Mosquito-Killer" 
• brit. Ground-Radar 
• 2. brit. Bomberstream 
• 2. brit. Mosquito 
• incl. programmable Start-Time-Points for V-1 and He-177

Expands:

    Duel in the Dark


Expanded by:

    Duel in the Dark: V1-Bunker

Name: Fleet Street
Description:
Fleet Street is a set collecting game based on buying and selling newspapers. The value of a set depends on how up market the publications are - lowest points are awarded for evening papers (6) then provincials (16), then dailies (24), then Sundays (32) then weeklies (40) then magazines (48). The players don't wait turns but on the word "Go" from the dealer start shouting the name of the paper they want to sell by trading cards. The first to collect a complete set and lay them down shouts "Fleet Street" and scores the points for that set. The cards are reshuffled and dealt again. Winner is the first to reach 250 points.
Each of the 48 newspapers/magazines have their own individual depiction of the front page - the magazines are especially colorful.

Name: Behold
Description:
Behold: The Christian Knowledge Game

A Bible trivia game.  Players roll the "Symbolized Cube" to move their marker to the next matching category square on the board.  Then they answer questions in that category to collect a Passage card.  When the player has collected all four styles of Passage cards, they attempt to recite the verses from memory to win the game.  Players may return to a category to trade their Passage card for a different one.

Contents:
500 Question cards
100 Passage cards
10 Player tokens
1 Symbolized Cube (no dice).

Name: Madison Trivia
Description: Players answer trivia questions about Madison, Wisconsin, trying to move three game pieces into the center of the board to win.

Name: The Merry Game Of The Country Auction
Description: This is a simple auction game "depicting" a rural country auction. Items up for bid are various pieces of farm equipment.

Name: Baseball
Description:
This is a loose simulation of baseball for two players, designed for the piecepack. There’s plenty of luck involved, but some of the choices managers face in real life are represented here, such as how to pitch to certain batters, when to change your pitcher, and whether or not to go for that extra base. You’ll need a basic familiarity with the sport to play this game, as baseball rules are not outlined much here.

The game is five innings, though extra innings may be necessary. Optional rules are included.

Name: Giraffe
Description: The object of the game is to spin the spinner, and add the number of neck pieces to the body, without making it collapse. To win the game you must use up all your neck pieces and put the head on. The game components are: 1 base tray, 1 Giraffe body, 1 Giraffe head, 1 spinner, 28 pegs, instructions, box, and cardboard insert.

Name: Barrier
Description:
This game is played on an empty NxN square board (such as a 7x7 board).

Each player drops his stone on an empty cell. On each turn, each player must move his stone. The stone moves similar to a chess Knight, but in two steps rather than one. First it moves one (two) cell(s) in one direction, then two (one) cell(s) orthogonally (hence each player has two moves per turn). All positions moved to or jumped over turn into an impenetrable barrier for both players (i.e., they cannot be moved into or jumped over).

Whoever leaves his opponent with no move first wins.

Name: Megalopolis
Description:
A sort of Monopoly clone developed and produced by Globo Giocattoli. Differs from the classic Monopoly for the names of the various "properties" (replaced with the names of cities, such "Rome", "London" and so on, grouped by country).

Also, the player range is different, allowing for a maximum of 8 players instead of 6.

A portable version of Megalopolis has also been released by Globo Giocattoli: this version is for 2-4 players and is contained in a small plastic wallet which can be brought around easily.

Rules are almost identical to the ones in Monopoly, with the exception of some small differences.

Name: Travel Manners of the Wealthy and Powerful
Description:
This is a simple trivia game that only Ms. Manners could love.  The only component is a 50-card deck with 6 questions on each card.

Sample questions:
A slap on the back to a European is considered a pure sign of friendship, true or false?

It is improper to address a man or woman of equal age or status as Sir or Madam, true or false.

The game is not from Funtastic Games of the 1960's, but FunTastic Games of Charlotte, NC.

Name: Boppin' Bee
Description: Use your flower bopper to snatch the honey chip from the Boppin' Bee as he buzzes around in a circle. Snatch more honey chips than your opponents and you'll be the winner!

Name: Ladybug Dominoes
Description:
Glückskäfer Domino or Ladybug Dominoes is a German children's game that uses cards shaped as ladybugs with unique spots on their wings. Ladybugs can be turned forward or backward to match spots as they are placed in a row. The first player to place all their cards is the winner.

The English name of the game on the side of the box was mistranslated as "Ladybird Dominoes."

Name: Coco Colecto
Description:
As with all games from this publisher there are a lot (11 in this case) rules variant so it builds up from 3 to 10 years.

From the publishers website:

Life of the ladybirds is one big feast, just as long as there are enough plant lice to eat and they stay out of harms way for instance coming from the spider webs, and of course the spiders themselves.
Would you like to chase for twins, go for a plant lice hunt or race against your friends? Then come and play Coco Colecto!

The game challenges children to use their arithmetical skills to get ahead in the game(s). Although the winning strategies depend on the smart use of additions, subtractions, multiplications and/or divisions, the learning process is almost invisible for the children, since they are too busy having fun. Coco Colecto is a versatile game with different levels of learning, which all draw upon the developing arithmetic skills of children.

Name: Tumble-Numbers
Description:
Tumble-Numbers is an interesting dice game similar to Shut the Box except that instead of a box with fixed numbers (1 to 9), it uses a set of ten red six-sided dice with non-standard numbers (as high as 10 and including blanks) to generate the numbers that have to be eliminated by rolling a pair of ordinary green six-sided dice.

The blanks can be used to represent any positive number but must always be removed together with another red die not showing a blank.

A player keeps on rolling the green dice and removing red dice that add up to the total on the green dice at each turn. When the player cannot do this, they take the sum on the remaining red dice as their penalty score (blanks count 20 points). When the player manages to get rid of all red dice, they subtract 10 points.

When a player reaches 100 points or more, he/she has to drop out. The last surviving player is the winner.

Name: Supermarina I: The First Part of the Mediterranean War – Scenarios and Statistics for Command at Sea
Description:
The First Part of the Mediterranean War - June, 1940 to July, 1941.

Contains Scenarios:

First Blood, Bagnolini vs. Calypso
Action Off Calabria (Punta Stilo)
Cape Spada
Ajax and Convoy MB6
Rainbow's End (Brit SS vs. Italian SS)
The Taranto Raid
Otranto Straits
The Fight off Cape Teulada 
The Inshore Squadron at Bardia
Operation Excess
The Vega Incident
Attack on Illustrious
Bombardment of Genoa
Convoy to Tripoli
Disaster in the Gulf of Bomba
Suda Bay
The Sinking of Bonaventure
Kerkennah Bank
The Conte Rosso Convoy
Black Thursday: The Battle for Crete
Night Action in the Kasos Straits
The Lupo Convoy
The Sagittario Convoy

Clash of Arms Stock #9509-53B

Name: Murkku
Description:
Murkku - a puzzle to solve for the kids

2-4 players
Ages 5 and up
The length of the game about 30 minutes

Idea of the game:

To over throw your opponent and get rid of the ants.

Name: Game of Siege
Description: This is a very early game by Milton Bradley Co. of Springfield, Massachusetts.  Enclosed in its box are 14 stand-up soldiers and a “rapid-fire, repeating pistol”. The purpose of the game is to shoot down as may of the soldiers as you can during your turn. The instructions are included on the back of the box lid. Components include, an officer on a horse, a bugler, a drummer and 11 riflemen. All stand 6-1/4” tall by means of the wooden blocks nailed to the bases of the men. The pistol is composed of wood & tin metal. It measures 5-1/2 inches in length and shoots small pegs of wood. The hammer is pulled back into a locking position and the ‘slugs’ are launched when the trigger is pulled.

Name: My First 3 Nature Games
Description:
Enjoyable adventures with animals in the form of dominoes, memory cards and an ancient board game. Leading children to the discovery of nature and helping to strengthen essential learning skills, all games are combined in a smaller 3-drawer storage box made of durable, recycled materials.

For players ages 3 and up, these games are the perfect pace and stimulation for younger ones. Contents: Baby Animals Memory Game (9 large "Mother" cards and 18 "Baby" cards); Who's Afraid of the Fox? (1 large game board, 4 figurines, 1 illustrated die); and Hide- And-Seek Dominoes (28 dominoes that show animals unique ways of protecting themselves). Grade "A" according to ToyTips.com, and a special gift to share especially with young ones.

Name: Prognos
Description: A Zodiac-themed Parcheesi-variant. Players move glass beads across the board from their starting position to target positions and back again. They draw cards to determine these target locations, which represent planets and zodiac signs. Die rolls determine how far a player can move. First visit all targets and return all beads wins.

Name: Team Work: Feste & Feiern
Description:
How's this supposed to work again? What happens when a team of two explainers are supposed to describe a concept but can only say the sentences together? But it gets better: the players can't discuss what they want to say ahead of time and must build the sentence while alternating words! A good time is guaranteed because the rest all try to figure out what the concept is at the same time. Who will have the most points?

This set of Teamwork "Feste & Feiern" covers the topic festivities and celebrations.

Expands:

    Team Work Original

Name: Scrimmage
Description:
Scrimmage was invented by Chuck Eskridge, and David Williams.  It is a football game in which one side controls the offense and the other controls the defense. Movement is accomplished by dice rolls, with slower players have lower maximum movement capability. Each side has pieces (players) of varying strength and speed.  Any player can tackle any other player, but only players of equal or greater strength can block opposing players.  The offense sets up, and then the defense, with a twist: the defense does not know whether the offense is running a passing play or a running play. (The choice is disclosed after the play starts.) If it is a passing play, the pass can be thrown to a designated grid but only after the play has had time to develop.  If a play breaks down, the offensive player draws a card to determine whether he can recover.

The passing mechanism works wonderfully: the offense places two men downfield in one of several grids, and secretly chooses a card identifying the grid to which the pass will be made. Each team then moves players (including the potential receivers) with the roll of the dice. When the pass is made, the offense chooses which square in the grid the pass will go to. The choice of squares determines how easy it is for the receiver and the defensive back(s) to get to the square to which the pass is made: if the receiver gets to the square and the back does not, the pass is complete.  If the back gets to the square and the receiver does not, the pass is intercepted.  If both get to the square, the pass is incomplete.

The running game and the pass rush depend on the the success of the blockers and the defensive line.  There is luck in the dice rolls, of course, but the luck evens out over the course of the game and a good play can survive a little bad luck.  Card drawing can also be important. Sometimes tacklers reach the ball carrier but fail to make the tackle, or make the tackle and force a fumble, which can be recovered by either the offense of defense.

This is one of the few games non-simulation football games (i.e., not strat-o-matic football or its cousins) that really feels like you are playing football.  You choose your play in advance, and, like real football, sometimes it works as planned, sometimes it fails, and sometimes you have to improvise during the course of the play.

Only about 800 copies of the game were sold, primarily in game stores in the South.  Two versions were created, the original version and a second version that included an optional "monster man" with good speed and power.

This game is not to be confused with the SPI game of the same name-- and almost the same year.

Name: Hypercube Hop
Description:
Hypercube Hop is the first game from Brane Games. 2-6 players each take turns to move their individual wooden pieces one step around a flat representation of a four-dimensional space, collecting small stones as they pass over them. At the end of the game, the player with the most stones wins.

The appeal in the game comes from the simplicity of the rules and the different strategies that are needed when playing with different numbers of players. Advanced players will discover that careful negotiation can allow them to strategically "fence in" players who take an early lead, giving rise to diplomatic gameplay.

Name: Atlantic City Tycoon
Description: Subtitled "The Ultimate Casino Dice Game", Atlantic City Tycoon is a roll-and-move game that has four dice games incorporated within it: Beat the Dealer, Chuck a Luck, Under and Over Seven, and Hazard. The game is clearly aimed at the family market but the dice games are real and the game tries to simulate a fun night in ACY.

Name: Maisy's First Game Book
Description:
Description from publishers web page:

Let the games begin! Join Maisy and her friends in a mad dash around the supermarket, collect the gold crowns in a terrific treasure hunt, and race for the finish line in a totally grand Grand Prix. With its built-in spinner and a selection of game pieces, MAISY'S FIRST GAME BOOK has everything preschoolers need to play five fantastic, fun-packed board games, Maisy-style.

Spin the spinner and see if you’re a winner with this bright, bold book of simple, lively games. One more way to be crazy for Maisy!

Name: Game of Old Mrs. Goose
Description: Child's Spin and Move Game from Milton Bradley (#4740)  comes with a spinner and 4 colored men. The spiral shaped board has special colored dots (Black, white and Red) which have special rules for them (lose turn, spin again, etc.)

Name: Paper Football Card Game
Description:
Do you remember playing the paper football game that got you in trouble in class growing up?
Now there is a different twist of competitive strategy added when playing this Paper Football Card Game. 
Players can make offense and defense plays and create fumbles and interceptions on their opponent. 
Also, kick off returns, challenged plays, point conversions and field goal attempts,are all part of the game.

Game Includes: 
100 cards,signature paper football, and rules.
Also, while supples last your order will include a Turf Card which is used to help 
kick the paper football for field goal and extra point attempts on slick surfaces.

Check out our website at www.rayzorsharpent.com

Name: Tuunes
Description:
Tunes is played either by two players or two teams. The game is played by selecting a card that has the notes for a popular melody printed on it. This card is placed in a special holder with numerous slots that can open to reveal one note at a time. Numbered tiles are then drawn randomly from a bag that tell which note to reveal. The melody that is visible is then sang, sight-read, or played on an instrument. The player who is able to identify the melody with the least amount of notes shown is the winner.

The game includes card packs for various genres of music including classical and religious hymns.

Name: Finanssinero
Description: Finanssinero is a stock market game involving the biggest Finnish companies. It is possible to buy and sell shares and use prognoses to predict future market development.

Name: Pizza Box Football 2007 Expansion Game Booster
Description:
The expansion builds on the Pizza Box Football game system.  Offenses and defenses can call more aggressive plays, and players can play for their favorite team.

All 32 teams from the 2006-2007 season are modeled after their strengths and weaknesses.  How will you shut down Indy's powerful passing?  Penetrate Baltimore's stalwart defense? Slow Tennessee's running QB?

This game includes 2 cards for using the expansion game play calls on offense and defense.  Beware of the defense's blitz!  Watch out for the screen pass!

Teams are updated every year, and 2 free teams are made available for free download for players who want to play the Big Game before it happens.

Expands:

    Pizza Box Football
Families: Game: Pizza Box Sports (On The Line Game Company)

Name: Rumbling Spell Orchestra
Description:
Rumbling Spell Orchestra is a CCG based on the "Touhou Project" series of Japanese shoot-em-up games. They're what the Japanese call "danmaku" games, literally "bullet hell," a genre known for it's manic focus on dodging extremely complex bullet patterns, where thousands of deadly projectiles can fill the screen at a time. The Touhou games are known for their intricate and complex bullet patterns, unique fantasy setting, many characters, and prodigal amount of fan-derived works...this card game included.

"This is a two-player turn-based dueling card game. Each player starts out by choosing four characters (repeats are allowed), and designates one as the leader. Your leader has an initial health point (HP), border value (BV) and evasion value (EV), which will be used throughout the match, as well as some special abilities. Your starting spell point (SP) is zero. The other characters are to allow you access to other cards; the character requirements can be seen at the top of each card.

After you've picked your team, you get to choose 40 cards (duplicates are allowed up to a total of three) that comprise your deck. Obviously you will pick cards that you can actually use.

You will keep track of your HP and SP using counters. The game ends when one person's leader's HP drops to zero or when his or her deck has been depleted."
Families: Video Game Theme: Project Shrine Maiden

Name: Don't Drop the Soap
Description:
From the publisher:

Fight your way through 6 different exciting locations in hopes of being granted parole. Escape prison riots in The Yard, slip glass into a mob boss' lasagna in the Cafeteria, steal painkillers from the nurse's desk in the Infirmary, avoid being cornered by the Aryans in the Shower Room, fight off Latin Kings in Gang War, and try not to smoke your entire stash in The Hole.

The artistry of each handcrafted piece is matched with comparable humor & intelligence on every card. Stack your smokes, sharpen your shank, and get ready for an experience that only someone on the outside could appreciate.

Name: Sturmpioniere
Description:
One of the more interesting wargame designs coming out of Nazi Germany.

The game features 4 duplicate triangular maps of the field of battle that can be placed together to form a square board.  Each section of the map contains 90 points with various obstacles that must be overcome (minefields, hedgehogs, wire fences) or repaired (blown bridges, destroyed roads). The playing pieces are metal miniatures (painted flats) consisting of German Sappers with various implements (explosives, wire cutters, Flame-thrower, etc.) and a tank.

The sappers move based on a die roll, in any combination the player desires.  The object of the game is to overcome obstacles by gathering the right combination of sappers at the obstacle which is either then destroyed or repaired for the rest of the game.  The final obstacle is a bunker that sits on the intersection of all four boards and must be destroyed to win the game.

Name: The Ocean Race
Description: A Spears roll-and-move game featuring metal pawns shaped like boats.  One of many Spears roll-and-move games of the period.

Name: The Tram
Description: A simple roll-and-move game featuring what, at the time, was cutting edge transportation.

Name: Blockade
Description:
From the Rules: Blockade is played with multi-shaped wooden pieces representing Naval Formations, Air Units, Submarines and Cargo Ships on a six-color map.  Victory consists of capturing or sinking all enemy Merchant Shipping so that the enemy is completely blockaded and cannot obtain further supplies from Neutral sources.

The Map shows four countries (two sets of paired enemies).  The land war between them is considered to be locked in a Maginot Line type of stalemate so the battle hinges on the war at sea.  The map has 32 ports (5 in each warring country and 12 on the coasts of the neutrals).

Each country has a different starting mix of units (for example Leoland is high in Naval Formations and Adlerreich has the most submarines).  The player round consists of moving all your cargo ships 1 space then rolling the dice and moving your units. A player may make a single air attack instead of moving any naval units.  The air units have unlimited range and the number required to make an attack is based on the target.  Losses are also based on the target and are automatic (for example it takes 4 air units to attack a naval formation and 2 air units are automatically lost).

A merchant ship can join a naval formation and create a convoy for more protection. Naval combat consists of a surprise attack (by submarines) and open attacks between naval formations.  The surprise attack can be triggered by a roll of 8 or higher and an open attack requires the player to spend 1 or 2 pips of the dice roll.

Name: Battle at Sea: The New Game of National Defense
Description:
From the rules - Battle at Sea, the new game of National Defense, is played on a cloth surface which is marked with two sea lanes of 16 spaces each.

Players assume control of a fleet and moves his fleet through his respective sea lane attempting to sink as many ships of the enemy fleet as possible.  When one fleet has been moved completely through its sea lane, the battle is over.  The player who sinks the greatest amount of enemy tonnage is the winner.

Special embossed dice are used to determine hits.  Gunnery ranges, destroyers laying smoke screens, and aircraft carriers allow for varied game play.

A very rare game of naval combat

Name: Conquest
Description:
From the rules: In brief the purpose of the game is to conquer as many of the 48 states shown on the map of the United States as possible.

Description from the rulebook:

Three hundred years ago the world powers were moving.  Far off to the west a great unknown wilderness was opening up. North America was being conquered and empires were being built.  Today in the game Conquest we re-enact the conquering of the continent.

It is a game in which keen judgement interspersed with dashes of bluff and audacity mingle with lady luck to create a game that on one is out of until the last hand is played.

The purpose of the game is to conquer as many of the 50 states shown as possible.  States must be conquered in the order listed under "Order of Conquest" shown on the game board and are also one of either four colors and have a number associated with victory points at the end of the game.

There are four phases to the game - 1) Bidding your hand, 2)Marking of conquered territory and distribution of groups, 3)Dealing new cards, 4) Additional conquest.

In the bidding phase, players bid on their hand of five cards. First player is to the right of the dealer and then in subsequent hands, the winner of the previous hand starts the bid.  Starting player places a bid.  Bids cannot be higher than $5 million.  The remaining players can either pass, meet the bid or raise the bid.  Winning hands are determined in order of winning hierarchy: Single: Highest single card of color called for; Doubles: Two matching number cards, one in the color being called; Triples: Three matching number cards, one in the color being called; Sweep: All four cards of the same number.

In the second phase, the winner of the hand takes all money bid and places one of their markers on the state or states conquered, receiving the number of regiments of troops as indicated on the conquered state.  5 regiments = 1 division.  Only divisions can be placed on the maps in any territories the players owns. Players may redistribute any troops that he possesses for the purposes of defense or offense. Players can also purchase additional troops.

In the third phase, the dealers asks if everyone is ready for the deal.  The dealer hands out enough cards to bring all players hands up to five cards. If a player receives a money card they can immediately turn the card in to collect the cash and gets another card.

In the final phase, players may conquer states of their opponents. Starting with the player who won the last hand states can be conquered via the following rules: 1)State must adjoin the territory of conqueror and belong to an opponent 2) Must have more troop divisions that place being conquered 3) Player must pay bank sum of 10 million plus 5 million for every divsion that opponent has in the conquered territory (Max 40 million) 4) Only one state can be conquered per hand 5) Conquered troops are returned to opponent and 6) if conquests results in a complete territory being possessed than additional troops are obtained for the district.

To conclude the game: After all states have been conquered there is a final phase of general conquest until no one has any resources left to conquer with.  The winner is the player having the highest score by totaling the victory points associated with the states conquered.

Name: GHQ
Description:
From the rules:  G.H.Q. is a Strategic war game for two players, one player representing the Allied Armies and the other the German Army.  The theater of War is the Western Front and the territories of countries adjacent to that front.  The Object is to occupy ONE of two capital cities of the opponent.

On the map the principal towns are shown as red circles and connected together by thick red lines which represent the road and railway systems.  Towns with black centers are Corps garrison towns and the associated units are marked on the map.  The units (armoured, motorized and infantry corp) are represented by different shaped wooden pieces with Flags attached.

The Germans always go first and movement is governed by a roll of the dice.  The roll will be between 1 and 3 and the number thrown indicates the number of units which may be moved.  Armoured corps can move 3 spaces, Motorized 2 and Infantry 1 space.  Destruction of units is based on having units adjacent to the target enemy, 3 friendly units are required to kill an armoured unit, infantry and motorized are destroyed by two friendly units in adjacent towns.  For every enemy unit destroyed the player gets another roll.

Name: The H. V. Kaltenborn Game of Diplomacy
Description:
The goal of the game is to be the Diplomat that creates the Greatest World Empire by controlling strategic location cards, collecting Colony and Independent Country Flag cards, capturing soldiers, battleships and bombers.

The map consists of a circle of spaces with flags representing various countries of the world, across the center of the circle is the Bridge of Flags representing the six great colonizing countries.  At the beginning of the game players pick one of the six great countries as their home country.  They get one Diplomat, 10 consulates, 5 soldiers, 1 bomber and 1 battleship.  The battleship and bomber are placed on the home country flag and all the diplomats are placed on "Start".

The mechanic of the game consists of movement around the path of flags via the roll of dice (doubles get a second roll). When a player lands on a colony he places a soldier, a second landing on the same colony gains a consulate and the Country Flag card.  Landing on an independent country gains an immediate colony.  Soldiers can be captured if another player lands on a colony before a consulate is placed.  Players can move across the Bridge of Flags if they land on one of the two Neutral Countries, doing so gains the player a battleship or bomber.  The battleship or bomber can be used to gain a strategic location flag if he owned when he lands on a strategic location. Normally players can only move clockwise but control of a strategic location allows the player to move either direction when he lands on one.  Additional game play is added via card play introduced by landing on an "Isolation" spot.

The game ends when one player has placed 10 consulates.  Flags, and captured tokens are worth points and the player with the most points at the end wins the game.

Name: Lentävä Matto
Description:
Two Sultans are flying together on a magic carpet, but they both want to take their possessions with them.

Every turn the player chooses one item to put on the magic carpet and sends it over to the other player without dropping anything off the carpet on the way.

Name: Plasticopoli
Description:
This game was designed to popularize plastic recycling in a time in which it was still pretty unusual, at least in Italy. Players must set a collection of 4 diofferent plastic objects, getting them from leftovers of plastic. Double objects can be either traded or destroyed to get more raw materials. Leftovers can also be burned to get energy.

The game has been published as a large magazine to be diostributed for free in schools all over Italy.

"Il gioco dei minerali" is reminescent of this game: Il Gioco dei Minerali

Name: The Juno Mission
Description:
Players are astronauts that have arrived at Star City for their final phase of training.  Only one player will join the two Cosmonauts on a trip to the Mir Space Station.

In this roll and move game, you must collect a Pass Card for languages, medical fitness and technical skills and get to the Launch Pad first.

In the Advanced Game, the game lasts 26 turns (weeks) and the winner of the game is the player who reaches the Launch Pad having collected the most points from going round the board, with Pass Cards from the Basic Game counting as 5 points.

Name: Pog Baseball
Description:
From the publishers website:

POG Baseball combines the Classic Game of POG with the real action of baseball. You can score a run, hit a triple or strike out. You must outscore your opponent by flipping over the most POG. The player who scores more points wins the game! Includes 22 POG, 2 Slammers, 1 Game board, 1 Die, 1 Official Rule Sheet and 1 Score Pad.

Reimplements: Pogs

Name: Pog Basketball
Description:
From the publishers website:

POG Basketball combines the Classic Game of POG with the real action of basketball. You can make 3 point shots and slam dunks but be careful, you can also shoot an air ball. You must outscore your opponent by flipping over the most POG. The player who scores more points wins the game! Includes 22 POG, 2 Slammers, 1 Game board, 1 Die, 1 Official Rule Sheet and 1 Score Pad.

Reimplements: Pogs

Name: Pog Football
Description:
From the publishers website:

POG Football combines the Classic Game of POG with the real action of football. You can get a first down or score a touchdown but be careful you can also fumble the ball. You must outscore your opponent by flipping over the most POG. The player who scores more points wins the game! Includes 22 POG, 2 Slammers, 1 Game board, 1 Die, 1 Official Rule Sheet and 1 Score Pad.

Reimplements: Pogs

Name: Pog Soccer
Description:
From the publisher's website:

POG Soccer combines the Classic Game of POG with the real action of soccer. You can score a goal, make a save or get a red card. You must outscore your opponent by flipping over the most POG. The player who scores more points wins the game! Includes 22 POG, 2 Slammers, 1 Game board, 1 Die, 1 Official Rule Sheet and 1 Score Pad.

Reimplements: Pogs

Name: Pog Hockey
Description:
From the publisher's website:

POG Hockey combines the Classic Game of POG with the real action of hockey. You can score a goal, make a save or get a penalty. You must outscore your opponent by flipping over the most POG. The player who scores more points wins the game! Includes 22 POG, 2 Slammers, 1 Game board, 1 Die, 1 Official Rule Sheet and 1 Score Pad.

Reimplements: Pogs

Name: Basquete S.A.
Description:
From the Publisher: Buy, sell, trade... In this game you'll also be the star of your team, creating strategies to beat your adversaries e win the championship. Your team fans are a important aspect - the larger the crowd in your arena, more money you'll make. Therefore you'll be able to buy the season best players for your squad building a super team.

NBA licensed game.

Name: Conquering Hollywood
Description:
Conquering Hollywood is the first board game about what it is really like to be in California making your dream of success in the movie business a reality. It's also the first game with "Personality Power," a way to compete with other players outside of the game itself ... that counts in the game.

The game of Conquering Hollywood is based on "Personality Power." That means everything you say and everything you do counts in the game. Even things you say and do "outside the game."

Conquering Hollywood is a cutthroat look at the true ways and means of Tinseltown. Actors! Producers! Directors! Writers! Just a Nobody? Get a car and pick up a screenplay. Compete with other players to make hit movies. Whether you're a nobody or a player, everyone in Tinseltown wants to be King of Hollywood!  But there is only one King and his joy lasts only 15 minutes after an intense, hand-to-hand battle. To succeed at the game of Conquering Hollywood, you have to compete with the same people who used to be your friends. You have to compete all the time without losing concentration for a second. Compete for what? For possession of the things you need to make hit movies.

To "make it" in the movie biz in this game you need the following items: story, game, money, talent, style, vision, fight, grind, luck, call, wires, and looks.

Name: Attack
Description:
The object is to attack, capture and destroy enemy camp or ammunition dump by placing a shell, bomb tank or men within them.

Play is started by placing men & mortars in camps; guns and tanks in ammunition dumps, airplanes at home airdromes.  Mine locations are secretly noted.  Units are moved 1 at a time within the allowed movement range.  Units can capture multiple enemy units simply by entering their square or they can shoot and destroy a single unit per turn.  First player to capture or destroy an enemy dump or camp wins the game.

Name: Im Obstgarten
Description: A Pachisi variant (roll and move, be the first to bring your 4 pieces to the target area, 2 pieces act as a barrier and so on ...). Slightly altered rules (one piece is on the track already). Most interesting and very nice idea in this edition: the game board is a large printed table cloth (approximately 1 by 1 meter).

Name: Controversia
Description: A mix between Scrabble and Othello.  The game is about creating words in a grid of 10x10; the players has the same tiles with letters, but one will play with the red side and the other player with the black side of the letters.  The idea is to make words using letters with the colour of your opponent.  That letters will now change to your colour, as in Othello. The player with the most letters of his own colour wins the game.

Name: Taking the Fort
Description: A very early wargame by Parker Brothers.  Up to four players spin a spinner in turn and move down a path to be the first one to take the fort.

Name: Kriegspiel Junior
Description:
The gameboard shows a battlefield containing Berlin and Vienna at one end and Paris and Brussels at the other (which appear to be represented by 3 gold circles).  Additional the map has fortresses (gold point walled in) and is dominated by a river running down the middle.

The game mechanics are an unknown at this point but its a point to point movement system.

Name: Waterloo
Description:
Very little is known about this game.  The map shows a area from Versailles and Paris on one side and Brussels and Namur on the other.  Key towns/cities (in gold) include Quatre Bras and Ligny.

It seems to be a forerunner for Kreigspiel Junior with its point to point movement system.  The gameboard is the top of the box (wooden) which also has a slot for the game pieces.

Two of the five known copies are part of the Angiolillo collection.

Name: The Game of 5th Column Spy Hunters
Description:
To quote the rules:  "Every 5th Columnist Spy that is caught pays the full penalty for his crime whether this country is at peace or at war.  For a while a 5th Columnist spy may escape detection and cause much damage and many heartaches… but from the days of old... No 5th Columnist Spy has yet escaped." Excerpted from the rules section A Word About Spies by James Boyle - Former Special Investigator.

5th Column  Spy Hunter is a point to point movement game for 2 teams.  Players act as either the 5th Columnists or the Spy Hunters and move around a map of the United States based on Official Number Code from the Decoder (a spinner).  The spinner provides moves based on a separate "code" list for 5th Columnists and Spy Hunters.  5th Columnists score points for ending their moves on designated spots (for example: air naval or army bases to steal documents), the Spy Hunters get points based on failures by the 5th Columnists.   The winner is the first team to 15 points.    Both teams are expected to record their routes so that a second game can be played to crown the "Champion Spy Hunter".  The teams exchange routes and take turns listing the order of the states they entered and their capitols.  Points are awarded for correct answers. Mistakes cost a team their turn.  The Champion is the team with the highest score.

Name: Tomtespelet
Description:
Two game variants:
Tomtespelet and "Tomten and Trolls" (Tomten are Swedish dwarfs). Both with elements of Checkers and Focus.

Produced by Ravensburger with nice components, though the title giving Tomtespelet is totally broken as far as I recall (probably due to a rule error).

Name: Schachy
Description: A chess variant on a larger board with more pieces per player. A die roll determines which kind of chess move can be made with a piece in the player's turn.

Name: Latest Game of Knights, Tournaments, and Saracens for Young and Old
Description: Beautiful game created via lithography in Nuremberg, despite the impressive name, it appears to be a simple roll-and-move game.  It's pictured in Games We Play.

Name: New Traveling Game by Railway from Berlin to Paris
Description: A game created via lithograph in Nuremberg.  It's pictured in Games We Play, and the box cover is both beautiful and very impressive for 1840.

Name: The New Game of the Monkey
Description: A very simple spin-and-move game, intended to be played with a tee-totem. As with similar games, player race along a track, attempting to be the first to reach the finish. A few spaces on the track have a special effect.

Name: Freischütz
Description: Published in Nuremberg in 1821, the game components consist of a board, 12 cards, 7 balls, and two dice and is based on the important German opera which hit the stage in the same period.

Name: Historical-Chronological Game
Description: Mentioned in Games We Play as one of the earliest published games, used by Gutsmuths categorization of games, which was published in 1796.

Name: Geographical Card Game
Description: Mentioned in Games We Play as one of the earliest games, it was mentioned in Gutsmuths' 1796 book that created a classification method for all games.

Name: Throne and Cottage
Description: According to Games We Play, this is the predecessor to Bell and Hammer.

Name: Yacht Race
Description: A simple roll-and-move game from Spears in a period when they were releasing several such games in any given year.

Name: Word Builder
Description: The forerunner to Scrabble, this Spears game had everything Scrabble has except the crossword element.

Name: Wir fahren gegen Engeland
Description:
The game consists of a map of the North Sea, showing the United Kingdom, coasts of Norway, Denmark, Germany, Belgium and France.  There are two paths of points that wrap around England and in each part are points of conflict (numbered to match lists supplied in the rules).

Cards with silhouettes of target ships are supplied to match the numbers. The cards include vital data regarding tonnage and size and a number that represents the roll needed to sink the ship.  The game also includes 3 plastic submarines and 3 plastic airplanes to represent the players.
